Award.AwardTitle: 5th ASM Conference on Beneficial Microbes; September 27-30, 2014, Washington, D.C.
Award.AbstractNarration:
The 2014 Beneficial Microbes Conference provides a forum for the exchange of the latest conceptual and technological research advances on resident microorganisms and their impact on the fitness of animals and plants. The meeting will bring together US and international researchers from multiple disciplines (microbiology, immunology, genomics, nutrition, ecology, systems biology, evolutionary biology and clinical science), and comprises five sessions: (1) Microbiota and the Gut-Brain Axis; (2) Evolutionary Dynamics of Host-Microbe Interactions; (3) Nutrition and Immune Function: Cross-Species Perspectives; (4) The Ecology of Host-Microbial Interactions; and (5) Beneficial Microbes in Human Health and Disease. Each session will include two invited talks, four talks selected from submitted abstracts and one further talk (invited or selected) with a quantitative flavor, to disseminate best practice in analysis of large datasets and facilitate discussion of outstanding barriers to computational analysis and mathematical modeling of host-microbial interactions. The conference will also include two poster sessions.
Biologists are increasingly recognizing that animals and plants are multi-organismal, i.e. invariably associated with benign or beneficial microorganisms. The 2014 Beneficial Microbes Conference will provide the opportunity to exchange ideas and information on these interactions, and explore exciting new opportunities to promote the health and vigor of animals/plants of economic and conservation importance, including agricultural crops, pollinators, and pests. The conference includes advertised opportunities for break-out groups to discuss specific scientific topics and issues in professional development (e.g. careers). A Conference Discussion on Future Directions in Beneficial Microbes Research will be the foundation for a published commentary on research priorities to overcome current barriers to advancement of the field. The conference will be particularly useful to promote opportunities for early-career researchers, women and minorities, through invitation and travel assistance, ensuring that these participants are well-represented and their scientific career opportunities are fully supported.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Beneficial Microbes Conference was held 27-30 September 2014, under the auspices of the American Society for Microbiology in Washington DC.  The goal for the conference was to provide a forum for the exchange of ideas and information on beneficial microbes.  There was a total of 295 attendees (244 from North America, 1 from South America, 27 from Europe, 18 from Asia, 1 from Australasia, and 4 from Africa). 

The opening keynote address by Professor Martin Blaser concerned the effects of antibiotic use on the beneficial microbes of humans.  Many respondents in the survey commenting specifically on the broad interest and high caliber of this presentation.  Professor Blaser participated fully in the conference activities, especially including interactions with early career-stage researchers. 

The core activity of the conference was five half-day topics, with no parallel sessions. Each session included two invited speakers (30 mins) who highlighted recent conceptual breakthroughs in the subject area, four speakers chosen from the submitted abstracts (20 mins), and one further talk (invited or selected) by an expert in quantitative methods, focusing on the latest computational and mathematical techniques, e.g. mining very large and heterogeneous datasets, predictive modeling and statistical inference.  Among the 36 talks, 49% were presented by junior scientists, 48% by female speakers, and 6% were provided by under-represented minorities (URMs).

Complementing the oral presentations, two 90 minute poster sessions were held, one on each of the two full days, were organized.  At each session, half of the presenters will be in attendance at their poster for discussion. All posters were on display throughout the meeting close to the main lecture hall, to promote easy viewing and informal discussion with the poster presenters.  A total of 172 posters were displayed, with the distribution of first authors as follows: 86 men and 86 women; 26 URMs; 76 international participants.  The survey results indicated that these sessions were greatly valued for informal discussion of scientific topics and for networking and general communication.

The conference included a Discussion of Future Directions in Beneficial Microbe Research, led by Professor Margaret McFall Ngai.  The discussion was driven by the floor, and focused principally on routes to promote the discipline, enhance the representation of the discipline in higher education curricula, and engage with the wider community.  This event was identified as a highlight by many respondents to the questionnaire, and was also listed as one of the highlights of the conference in the bimonthly report to the Executive Director of the American Society for Microbiology.
